My concern is that this could be used (intentionally or not) as a DoS tool for the RDO registry. Running multiple concurrent jobs or running a job that pushes several large images could be an issue.

I have been researching the RDO Registry options, and there is currently no way to set up a proper quota. We can set a quota for the number of imagestreams [1], but that only limits the number of images with different name (e.g. centos, fedora, whatever). We could push as many images with the same tag as we wanted (centos:7.1, centos:7.2, centos:7.3...), so it is not an efficient way of setting up the quota. Also, there is no way to limit the amount of storage used by the imagestreams.

[1] https://docs.openshift.com/container-platform/3.11/admin_guide/quota.html#sample-resource-quota-definitions

x86 can include 32-bit systems and ppc is 32 and 64-bit systems running in either big or little endian.
point

A manifest is an aggregation of heterogenuous images. The images referred by the manifest don't even need to share the same layers. THey can be different images, different names, different tags, different size. In my experiments, I created a manifest with a centos and a fedora image. THe images are not embedded in the manifest, the manifest contains just pointers. We could debate about naming conventions, but using architecture tag is not the preferred solution, that's why manifests exist to address the multi arch problem. Tags in docker work differently from any other concept of tag. An image can have only a single tag. If you retag an image, you create two images with same base image id but different digests. If we use architecture tag, we lose the ability to identify the version of the image as you can't put the dlrn_has and the arch tag on the same image, and there's no way to pull an image based on two tags e.g. you can't do something like "docker pull image1:hash1:x86"

Aaahhh, you're adding arch to the existing tag instead of the name. That makes sense. The only concern I have is that if we are using only underscores in-tags and between tags, it would not be easy to parse the tag in the future, but I understand the choice. Thanks for the explanation.
to use manifests correctly it's my understanding that the names of the containers must be identical.  We will have to tag each container w/ the distro type, not change the name of the container

I think Jargon is confusing us.

In our development we used:

${container}:${tag}_${arch} for the architecture specific image/layer and then ${container}:${tag} for the manifest itself.  This was to ensure that all layers "included"[1] in the manifest could be pushed to a remote registry and trivially referred to locally  You *could* pull fu:bar_x86_64 onto a ppc64le system ... it clearly wouldn't "work" but you could inspect it.

What's critical is that the image presented as ${container}:${tag} on the "final registry" be the manifest image that works on both x86_64[2] and ppc64le

Which I *think* is what you're both describing but I want to be sure.


[1] I know the manifest does not include the data but just the SHA references
[2] Why docker used amd64 for this platform tag is beyond me :(
convention

The sequence to create a manifests is:
1) pull or create images locally
2) push images to registry
3) create manifest locally, pointing to images in registry
4) push the manifest itself

docker manifest will complain in many cases:
- All images referred from the manifest MUST come from the same registry
- THe manifest itself MUST use the same registry of all its slave images.
- you can't create manifests if the referred images are not present in the registry first.

- pull ppc containers from rdo-registry (name, tagged ppc )
- build the manifest
- push containers to docker.io using the manifest.

cinder/volume/drivers/hitachi/hbsd_rest..message: this isn't probably a problem but wondering if a interval of 0 would flood your storage APIs... Also, this could run eternally if you never get a success from delete_volume/delete_snapshot, since you don't have any kind of timeout. A timeout using FixedIntervalWithTimeoutLoopingCall with a driver specific configuration to let users tell how long to wait for this operation would help in this case. Considering the deadline for the feature freeze, I wouldn't oppose to work on this in a follow up patch but would like to know other's opinions.

The FixedIntervalLoopingCall is usually used for looping function call and the interval argument means the interval of repeated calls.
On the other hands, we use FixedIntervalLoopingCall for calling _delete_group_obj() in parallel on the child process. the _delete_group_obj() always ends with a single call.
So the value of the interval argument does not affect the operation of the Hitachi driver, and I think 0 is not a problem.
I'm not a fan of using a looping call for something that doesn't loop, using a normal thread from the threading module seems more reasonable.
I will consider whether the driver can use a normal thread. After investigation, I will submit the other patch.

I want to follow up on Fernando's question on an earlier patch set.  What you're doing here is putting each obj delete into its own loopingcall so that you can spawn them in parallel, but they'll never actually loop because you raise a LoopingCallDone unconditionally at the end of _delete_group_obj().  stop_on_exception is True by default for start(), so if an exception you're not looking for occurs, the loopingcall will terminate.  But then I think that exception will be re-raised when you call e.wait() below, which could mean that you don't complete processing the "for e in events" loop below.  I guess I'm worried that if you have a group of 5 items, the first 2 are deleted and the third raises an Exception you're not looking for, this function won't return and the model_update won't happen, and some deleted items won't have their status changed.  So while I think you're right that you don't have to worry about a nonterminating loop, this is kind of a nonstandard use of the loopingcall, and I'm not how safe this pattern you're using is.  You're doing a similar thing in create_group_from_src, but that's happening in a try block where you  save and reraise the exception after doing some other processing.

I'm not saying that you have to do the same thing here, I just want to make sure you've thought about this.
I agree with Gorka. I will submit the other patch to catch all exceptions or change to using normal thread.

OK, you know your backend better than I do, and I assume you've tested this code carefully.  You've obviously thought about it, which was the point of the question, so I don't think this is an issue that should delay the patch.

I think it would be best to either have a catch all exceptions on the wait, or have it on the _delete_group_obj, just to be sure, because even if today we are 100% sure that no other exception will happen, this may change in the future if we change delete_snapshot or delete_volume, and we may miss it and introduce a bug.

Hitachi driver's _delete_group() calls delete_volume() and delete_snapshot(). When an error occurs in these functions, raises one of the following exceptions: utils.HBSDError, exception.VolumeIsBusy, exception.SnapshotIsBusy. No other unexpected exceptions are raised, except for syntax errors and so on. Since the exceptions that delete_volume() and delete_snapshot() may output are caught and processed by _delete_group_obj(), I think that there is no problem.
On the other hand, create_group_from_src() raises an exception by itself when one of volume creation fails (hbsd_rest.py # 890). I am using the try sentence to catch this exception and are doing rollback processing to delete the created volume.

For informational purposes and better look into alternatives, could you please as well provide a few words on how that libvirt > qemu > kvm stack is built on Kubevirt? AFAIK it is total different to that we have in OpenStack and to that this spec proposes. That also means that whatever we'll chose -if not leaving it as is- either to uncontainerize, or switch to Kubevirt in future, the associated architecture changes would be quite a breaking anyways.

> For informational purposes and better look into alternatives, could you please as well provide a few words on how that libvirt > qemu > kvm stack is built on Kubevirt? AFAIK it is total different to that we have in OpenStack and to that this spec proposes. That also means that whatever we'll chose -if not leaving it as is- either to uncontainerize, or switch to Kubevirt in future, the associated architecture changes would be quite a breaking anyways.

The main difference of the kubevirt design is that kubevirt runs a dedicated set of libvirt
services with every virtual machine pod. So you have multiple libvirt service running in
different cgroup/namespaces for the vm on the worker node. 
e.g.

```
# oc get pods/virt-launcher-controller-0-w4whk
NAME                               READY   STATUS    RESTARTS   AGE
virt-launcher-controller-0-w4whk   1/1     Running   0          166m

# oc rsh virt-launcher-controller-0-w4whk
sh-4.4# ps -ef
UID          PID    PPID  C STIME TTY          TIME CMD
root           1       0  0 06:56 ?        00:00:01 /usr/bin/virt-launcher --qemu-timeout 5m --name controller-0 --uid 8b95aa5c-2df0-4146-9dc9-ac2101e46b31 --namespace openstack --kubevirt-share-dir /var/run/kube
root          16       1  0 06:56 ?        00:00:13 /usr/bin/virt-launcher --qemu-timeout 5m --name controller-0 --uid 8b95aa5c-2df0-4146-9dc9-ac2101e46b31 --namespace openstack --kubevirt-share-dir /var/run/kube
root          28      16  0 06:56 ?        00:00:04 /usr/sbin/libvirtd
root          29      16  0 06:56 ?        00:00:00 /usr/sbin/virtlogd -f /etc/libvirt/virtlogd.conf
qemu          71       1 99 06:56 ?        02:50:08 /usr/libexec/qemu-kvm -name guest=openstack_controller-0,debug-threads=on -S -object secret,id=masterKey0,format=raw,file=/var/lib/libvirt/qemu/domain-1-opensta
root        1554       0  1 09:42 pts/0    00:00:00 /bin/sh
```

For kubevirt to be used as hypervisor nova a nova kubevirt driver would be required. To run
on kubernetes/OCP a single privileged pod which runs libvirt service can be use, like it is
today.

Right now I don't see an openstack-nova driver for kubvirt coming. There was a POC for this ~1.5 years ago and it was stopped in favor of running a single libvirt on the OCP worker nodes which were compute nodes.

Thank you Martin,
do you think we should add Kubevirt as alternative? Or extra details for the possible future architecture changes, like uncontainerize -> containerize back to Kubevirt pods; or just do nothing and wait for Kubevirt to arrive, then switch onto it omitting the uncontainerization phase?
Should we also mention that we are likely to need migration path from containerized libvirt to non-containerized libvirt ?
Done

I believe the host's libvirt will takeover after a reboot of said host.

I just want to clarify that once the libvirt container is stopped, the qemu processes are not stopped and could, technically, be managed by the newly installed libvirt process on the host, assuming the version is compatible.

this item does not completely make sense to me. switching to use the host libvirt does not solve this challenge does it? and the challenge is not because of the use of containerized libvirt either. we can't update the host OS without also updating libvirt regardless of if libvirt is containerized or not.

I believe it's a bit more challenging to align the containerized version of libvirt with the host's kernel than simply letting the package manager on the host handle the constraint. We're kinda re-inventing the dependency wheel during updates instead of relying on good ol' yum/dnf.

[2] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/stable/train/nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py#L231-L239

The hotfix would target the nova_compute container. Nova's libvirt driver has a pretty wide range of compatibility matrix as mentioned above.
how? i don't see how this would happen. sure, a bug might cause the unexpected, but the same is true for non-containerized.

This could happen with a bug, user-manipulation (ie: wrong image in content-view, custom image with the wrong packages, etc)

what provides the qemu executable today? isn't it the libvirt container image (nova-libvirt container image)? so isn't this dependency already managed by the package repositories?

i could see if it was separate container images then you could have a mismatch there, but if it's one container image, i don't see how.

the qemu processes are detached from the libvirt container. If you bounced the libvirt container, the qemu processes are not getting restarted.

If we update the libvirt container, we could end up with a different version of libvirt managing older version of qemu. Yes, this could also happen on decontainerized.

Thinking of future FFE X->Z(A) or whatnot, and computes in the hybrid mode, there is a possibility we end up with a 3 different virtualization approaches coexisting within a single deployment. Let me clarify: there *might* be controllers running via CNV that replaces RHEV, there would be hybrid N-1 computes that running tenants workloads via containerized libvirt as it is today. And finally, the computes with decontainerized libvirt. So, 3 different virtualization stacks to support for such scenarios. Do we really want that?

Also, decontainerizing libvirt would surely block any other than RHEL options (RH CoreOS I'm looking at you), even if we don't have any plans for it yet...
as mentioned earlier, we need to validate that this is technically possible. has that been done?

I'm still working on a PoC because we don't want to be in that situation. So far, we've pulled most of config into a libvirt-base template and we plan to keep both libvirt-container and plain libvirt. We'd swap the resources registry as needed. This is Martin's idea.

I was assuming that the reboot of the host would be required but now that you mention this, I'll validate this as well.

a poc is not required, i just want to make sure it's technically possible before we agree to decontainerization, and then later find out we have no migration path.

Is the reboot of the host required? That means shutting down every instance or the live migration slide puzzle. There are other efforts underway to avoid the forced reboot during an upgrade due to the OS upgrade, so I'm pretty hesitant to start adding further constraints that would require it.

We're working on this. We have a PoC of decontainerizing that works right now and we're looking into the upgrade process in parallel. Should we have a PoC for the upgrade path before we submit a spec? I'm sorry, I'm not fully familiar with this.
I totally understand. We'd also like to have the feedback from Upgrades team before we merge.

i'd like to hold off on merging this spec until we know if a reboot will be required. There is a separate discussion about decoupling the OpenStack and RHEL upgrade, and one of the reasons that is desired is because it might avoid a reboot.

It would be pretty self defeating to move forward with this change that required us to reboot every compute node anyway.

need to also make sure there are ansible tasks (or puppet i suppose) that installs the packages as well given we support deploying with a rhel minimal image as well with nothing preinstalled, other than sshd.

I'm not a fan of adding the libvirt packages to the image as it would be on all the overcloud nodes, no matter what their role is. I wish we could install only with ansible/puppet when necessary, but I believe there might be some entitlement constraints during deployment in some cases.
i'm saying we'll have to do both
Ack we'll do.

Could you please consider the following two comments?

1. 
The validation of supported parameters looks common in NFV-MANO APIs [1].

> 400 Bad Request: If the request is malformed or syntactically incorrect (e.g. if the request URI contains incorrect query parameters or the payload body contains a syntactically incorrect data structure), the API producer shall respond with this response code. 

If it's true, isn't it better to write this code in `/api/api_common.py`?

[1] https://www.etsi.org/deliver/etsi_gs/NFV-SOL/001_099/013/03.05.01_60/gs_NFV-SOL013v030501p.pdf#page=18

2. 
I was a little worry about that error messages show only the first unsupported parameter.
If multiple unsupported parameters can be passed, error messages should contain all of them. 
In this sense, ``key != "filter"`` might have room for improvement in terms of scalability.
How about using `set`? like this:

```
supported_parameters = {'filter'}
unsupported_parameters = set(request.GET) - supported_parameters
if unsupported_parameters:
    msg = _("Not supported parameters: %s") % ','.join(unsupported_parameters)
```

        description="Base policy for all volume type encryption type "
                    "operations.  This can be used to set the policies "
                    "for a volume type's encryption type create, show, "
                    "update, and delete actions in one place, or any of "
                    "those may be set individually using the following "
                    "policy targets for finer grained control.",
        operations=<snip>
        deprecated_for_removal=True
    ),

The RuleDefault object supports a deprecated_for_removal parameter that will output a deprecated message in the sample file. I also think it leaves messages for the operator in the service's API logs, which this approach won't do.

https://github.com/openstack/oslo.policy/blob/master/oslo_policy/policy.py#L648-L649
https://github.com/openstack/oslo.policy/blob/c7fd9f4fcd43fb78534921530d981634ec516344/oslo_policy/policy.py#L690

I got clarification from Brian on this comment. It's to remind us that RULE_ADMIN_API will be deprecated in Y (so the check_str needs to change), but also that the deprecated_reason should be deleted because the base class will provide the reason in Y.

My understanding is that module utils get renamed by the ansible runtime so they always appear in the ansible.module_utils namespace even when they're hosted ouside ansible core. This doesn't apply to unit tests though.

So in metalsmith I've proposed[1]:
- make the import optional, set to none if import fails
- in main() check the imported are there, and fail if not
- make sure unit tests don't exercise main()

Alternatively, why not just move the imports inside main()? That is the only place they're used and they'll only get imported once since modules are run as executables

manifests/profile/base/ceph/mon.pp.message: This was happening at step 4 because OSDs are configured in step 3. I think with Ceph jewel you can create pools before the OSDs are up but from Ceph luminous (queens) this is not possible anymoreso this will fail.
I tested it on pike (jewel) and it worked.  Will test on queens/luminous.  Shouldn't we have a CI job for Ceph+default services in non-containerized deployments?
Are we still using this class to manage pools even in queens? Shouldn't that be something handled via ceph-ansible instead of this code?

From queens this problem is probably only solvable by moving the gnocchi upgrade command one step later ... my expectations with master code is that pools creation will just fail because the osds are not up yet

And we can't set dependencies at the puppet level because OSDs and MONs are frequently deployed on different nodes

If we don't want to (or can't) shift upgrade one step later and if we agree on supporting non-containerized deployments up to (and including) Pike (which used to deploy ceph jewel) maybe we can make this a stable/pike only submission?

that was my point indeed, either we rely on ceph-ansible from pike (then the change is not necessary) or we support non-containerized deployments with puppet-ceph (then this change probably breaks master) ... or we make it a stable/pike only change, and support non-containerized deployments up to pike ... even though we don't have CI for it?

tripleo_ansible/roles/backup_and_restore.message: Are you hitting any issue without the double quotes? Any warning, lint error? If this is a bug, please add the information to the patch description so we can track, backport accordingly.

This simple playbook shows that this won't work:

---
- hosts: localhost
  vars:
    tripleo_backup_and_restore_rear_simulate: false
  tasks:
    - name: Create the node backup
      command: rear {{ '-s ' if "{{ tripleo_backup_and_restore_rear_simulate }}" else '' }}-d -v mkbackup
      register: tripleo_backup_and_restore_rear_output
      when: tripleo_backup_and_restore_rear_output is undefined
      tags:
        - bar_create_recover_image


TASK [Create the node backup] **************************************************
task path: /home/jfrancoa/test_ansible.yaml:6
fatal: [localhost]: FAILED! => {"changed": false, "cmd": "rear -s -d -v mkbackup", "msg": "[Errno 2] No such file or directory: b'rear': b'rear'", "rc": 2}

PLAY RECAP *********************************************************************
localhost                  : ok=1    changed=0    unreachable=0    failed=1    skipped=0    rescued=0    ignored=0   


Even though the variable is set to false, jinja identifies that the variable is defined so it considers it as a true.

This syntax would work instead:

command: rear "{{ '-s' if tripleo_backup_and_restore_rear_simulate|bool else '' }}" -d -v mkbackup


if tripleo_backup_and_restore_rear_simulate == false:

TASK [Create the node backup] ***********************************************************************************************************************************************
task path: /home/jfrancoa/test_ansible.yaml:6
fatal: [localhost]: FAILED! => {"changed": false, "cmd": "rear '' -d -v mkbackup", "msg": "[Errno 2] No such file or directory: b'rear': b'rear'", "rc": 2}

PLAY RECAP ******************************************************************************************************************************************************************
localhost                  : ok=1    changed=0    unreachable=0    failed=1    skipped=0    rescued=0    ignored=0   

if tripleo_backup_and_restore_rear_simulate == true:

TASK [Create the node backup] ***********************************************************************************************************************************************
task path: /home/jfrancoa/test_ansible.yaml:6
fatal: [localhost]: FAILED! => {"changed": false, "cmd": "rear -s -d -v mkbackup", "msg": "[Errno 2] No such file or directory: b'rear': b'rear'", "rc": 2}

PLAY RECAP ******************************************************************************************************************************************************************
localhost                  : ok=1    changed=0    unreachable=0    failed=1    skipped=0    rescued=0    ignored=0
Of course :-D, but you got my point right? the variable was set to false and it still added the -s to the command.
It fails because you dont have rear :) in any case, this bug is invalid.
This doesn't make much sense to me..as this is a variable, it's not a fact so unless you are running this in a loop it will always be undefined.

deployment/keystone/keystone-container-p.message: Would it be better to also add constraints and allowed_values? What an operator could override this parameter to?
so if Keystone needs ";", why creating a parameter?

The default value is ",", but as far as I can tell Keystone depends on this being set to ";", so theoretically we could hard code this.  In theory you could set it to anything you want.

The SAML/Mellon equivalent "MellonMergeEnvVars" is explicitly called out in the Red Hat documentation as needing to be set:
https://access.redhat.com/documentation/en-us/red_hat_openstack_platform/16.0/html/federate_with_identity_service/steps#edit_the_mellon_configuration

Various online examples I can find explicitly set it to ";" including 
https://cloud.denbi.de/wiki/cloud_admin/elixir_OIDC/
 and even the O'Reilly "Identity, Authentication and Access Management in OpenStack" book.

tox.ini.message:
The deps option is ineffective in the ansible ini section. When running 'tox -e scenario_name', it will install the deps coming from the main [testenv]. then:

     -c {env:TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE:https://opendev.org/openstack/requirements/raw/branch/stable/train/upper-constraints.txt}
     -r {toxinidir}/requirements.txt
     -r {toxinidir}/test-requirements.txt
     ansible>=2

Morever, tox-ansible will manage all the ansible and molecule* dependencies by itself.

And as it will use the upper-constraints we will still have the issue here.

Actually, when you check the latest results of zuul jobs for the https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/validations-common/+/806681, you will see the molecule jobs are running successfully and dependencies are installed without conflict. In addition to the general tox jobs which are green after the rebase. 

The only issue is in the test-requirements.txt, which now isn't compatible with the openstack constraints, in the requirements-check job, because ansible-core isn't listed there.
I think https://releases.openstack.org/constraints/upper/master is the prefered method to specify these

I based this of other similar PRs (likes this one https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/charm-ceph-osd/+/778159 ) where it was suggested to use "format" parameter for the action with "human readable" default and option for machine readable (like json).

you are right that it would take out some complexity from the code. I pushed new update where I removed `format` argument from the actions and they all show yaml document in the output. However I still had to reformat it a bit because by default, data from neutron api is list of dictionaries which, when formatted into yaml, do not read very nicely.
```
  results:
    router-list: |
      - ha: false
        id: 22567d98-828e-4e7f-bdb2-2f1ea16fc979
        name: provider-router
        status: ACTIVE
```
I didn't like that `id` and `name` attributes are buried in the middle of the dict so I changed it a bit to look like this
```
  results:
    router-list: |
      22567d98-828e-4e7f-bdb2-2f1ea16fc979:
        ha: false
        name: provider-router
        status: ACTIVE
```
Now the structure is a dictionary where resource (router/network/etc..) IDs are keys and rest of the attributes are in dictionary associated with that key. I originally wanted to use `name` attribute as a key, but unfortunately those are not unique.

I've had an issue using this socket.gethostname() because my host had .project.serverstack in the end eg: (juju-ba233a-openvswitch-9.project.serverstack') and gethostname was not returning the full name which resulted in an empty agent_list. Reading the socket documentation I found this: "Note: gethostname() doesn’t always return the fully qualified domain name; use getfqdn() for that."

Changing to getfqdn() solved this issue to me.[2]


[1] https://docs.python.org/3/library/socket.html#socket.gethostname
[2] https://docs.python.org/3/library/socket.html#socket.getfqdn

Unfortunately, Openstack components are not consistent with the value used in "host" column, sometimes its hostname sometimes its fqdn, depending on the component and which api endpoint is called. 

In these specific cases we have to use hostname (without the domain part) because that's what's returned in the "host" column for "L3 agent", "DHCP agent" and "Loadbalancerv2 agent" resources.

We have functional tests that verify that our "get-status-*" actions return same list resources as associated "neutron *-list" commands so we should be covered in case this behavior would change.

Instead of "Bugfix LP: #1935013" there is a special syntax:

    Closes-Bug: #1935013

This will then automatically post a comment about this review on launchpad.

See https://docs.openstack.org/charm-guide/latest/making-a-change.html

Example: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/charm-neutron-api/+/801619

Also, we need to elaborate more in the commit message: we are removing the ntp installation because we now expect operators to use a subordinate ntp charm instead.

The commit message should look like

    One-line brief description
    <empty line>
    Multi-line details.

i.e. in your case:

    Remove ntp installation in ceph-fs
    
    We now expect operators to use a subordinate ntp charm
    instead.

See https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages#Summary_of_Git_commit_message_structure

Okay, I think we've discussed approach on IRC [1]. Seems like we have a feasible way forward based on tosky and gmann advices.

this is we disucssed in Denver PTG QA sessions [1]

We need two todo for this
- mark the external interfaces from plugins as stable interface 
- add that plugins in g-r

First part need to start with plugins which are used outside like Octavia in this case. We can start with service clients.

second part is secodn step of tempest plugins release we did in Rocky. Now most of the plugins are released in pypi so i think we should be good to add those in g-r.

[1] https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/stable-interfaces-from-tempest-plugins

My issue here is that tempest plugins are not libraries. There's no guarantee of stable API. If we want to do it the right way we need to extract common parts into a library and keep API contract there. Or make sure we run all affected Kuryr-Kubernetes jobs on octavia-tempest-plugin's gate pipeline.

IMO importing a tempest plugin is not a way forward, unless we accept the fact that stuff will break from time to time.

If I am not wrong (please, correct me), the manila group design sticks the consistent snapshot support in the driver level. So, a driver reports which kind of support for group it has: pool (group as consistency with volumes in the same pool), host (all groups are consistency) or None (all groups are not consistency). I dont have the option to report it for each pool. So, working with a backend with FlexGroup and FlexVol together, I need to choose one for all. As discussed at the collab review, looping calls spawn new greenthreads, and we have a pretty primitive interface to control these threads. I would strongly recommend against spawning new loopingcalls in the driver for this - this is a perfectly acceptable async operation that we can offload to the share manager just like we do in case of an async create share from snapshot. 

The driver could wait until a flexgroup job ID has been acquired - and then, return a dictionary with "status" set to "async_creating" (or something like that) to the share manager. We can check this return value in the share manager and rely on the asynchrounous share update routine (https://github.com/openstack/manila/blob/1d95424dd674ced8479c8dae8841fbe40b82322a/manila/share/manager.py#L4848-L4859) to record the share's status when it completes.

Just take care not to expose this status to end users, i.e., map it back to "creating" with the help of the view builder in these resources: https://github.com/openstack/manila/blob/master/manila/api/views/shares.py, https://github.com/openstack/manila/blob/master/manila/api/views/share_replicas.py, https://github.com/openstack/manila/blob/master/manila/api/views/share_instance.py

manila/share/drivers/netapp/options.py.message:
Following up on our discussion at the collab review, setting this to True is going to "break" existing deployments if deployers use "netapp_enable_flexgroup" and forget to set  "netapp_flexgroup_pool_only". It's possible that deployers may actually want this to be false for a mixed mode of operation - so that they can still use shares less than 400 GiB in size, or use share groups and share group snapshots, etc alongside flexgroup shares 

If the desire is to make greenfield deployments use flexgroups by default, the driver could just figure out if its a greenfield deployment (no shares exist) and assume this value is True; else, if the driver sees existing shares and realizes that this is a brownfield deployment, it can set this value to False. The value of the determination can then stay in the driver's private storage for the next time it restarts
I changed it to `False` as default.
will go away if you perform async creation..
Sorry, I didnt get it. What do you mean by "go away" ?!
both are confusing to me, even knowing a little bit this storage. maybe providing a more detailed description?

yeah, it is a bit confuse. I tried to explain more. See if it is better enough. Otherwise, could you suggest a different text ?!

In simple words, they are two timeout opts for retry operations:

netapp_flexgroup_aggregate_not_busy_timeout: FlexGroup is over a set of aggregate. It can only start creating when all of its aggregates are not being used to deploy another volume. If they are busy deploying it, the operation fails. Instead of returning an error, I am retring with that timeout.


netapp_delete_busy_flexgroup_snapshot_timeout: Busy Snapshots cannot be deleted, we must to split its clone. The split operation takes time. So, we wait for the split complete until this timeout.
